---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11176537449/job/31070110026)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11176537449/job/31070110271)
maintainer merge
maintainer merge

This is one of those completely unreadable theorem statements. I think rephrasing it might be in order, something like:
```suggestion
theorem Polynomial.isRoot_cos_pi_div_five :
    (4 • X ^ 2 - 2 • X - C 1 : ℝ[X]).IsRoot (cos (π / 5)) := by
```
or whatever is the correct notation for the polynomial.

I admit that it's easy to lose perspective about one's own work, but is it really so bad? I mean, it's just a quadratic equation :)

Personally I find `4 * c ^ 2 - 2 * c - 1 = 0` much easier to read than `(4 • X ^ 2 - 2 • X - C 1 : ℝ[X]).IsRoot (cos (π / 5))` but in any case I'd argue we should try to optimise for a statement which is likely to be most convenient to the downstream user.

Would you feel differently if the `letI` did not appear? I.e., if it read:
```lean
    4 * cos (π / 5) ^ 2 - 2 * cos (π / 5) - 1 = 0 := by
```

Separately, I have some reservations about using `Polynomial`. It's only a rule of thumb but I feel like the job of `Polynomial` is really to support the study of the type of all polynomials, rather than as the encoding for every expression of degree 2 or more that crops up.

Having said all that, I don't have especially strong feelings here and I will happily make the change if you still feel the same; I just wanted to share my thoughts.

> I admit that it's easy to lose perspective about one's own work, but is it really so bad? I mean, it's just a quadratic equation :)

Sorry, I misspoke, but it was exacerbated by the fact that I also rephrased the statement. What I meant to say was:

> This is one of those completely unreadable theorem ~~statements~~ *names*.

As far as the actual *statement* goes, I liked the `letI`. As for whether we have the `Polynomial` version or yours, let's have our cake and eat it too? We can have both!

I do see your point about `Polynomial`, but I think it's okay to use it for both purposes.
If you keep the name of your version as is, maybe we could have an alias, something like: `quadratic_root_cos_pi_div_five` (or you could just use this as the name if you prefer).

Ah right, it was the name to which you were objecting.

I hated it too so I've accepted your permission to deviate from standard naming and used `quadratic_root_cos_pi_div_five`.

Also added the `Polynomial` version.
I don't think these parentheses (and those below) are adding any clarity.
They're not adding *clarity*, changing the *associativity*.
I really don't like how long this name is. I think it's fine to deviate from usual naming standards for something like this, how about `cos_pi_div_five_equation` or `cos_pi_div_five_polynomial`?
I am happy to report that this horrible name is gone. I took Jireh's suggested `quadratic_root_cos_pi_div_five`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: the cosine of `π / 5` is `(1 + √5) / 4`
